user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CreateSocketName:
```c
void OS_CreateSocketName(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, const char *parent_name)
{
    size_t                       len;
    uint16                       port;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *sock;

    sock = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, *token);

    if (OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name), Addr) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        sock->stream_name[0] = 0;
    }
    if (OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(&port, Addr) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, ":%u", (unsigned int)port);
    }

    if (parent_name)
    {
        /* Append the name from the parent socket. */
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, "-%s", parent_name);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CreateSocketName:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No language extensions are present in the provided function body. The code uses only standard C constructs and standard library features: local variable declarations, pointer dereferencing, structure member access, sizeof, snprintf, casts (unsigned int), and calls to functions/macros whose names begin with OS_. There are no compiler-specific keywords or constructs visible such as __attribute__, __asm, typeof, statement-expressions (GCC ({ ... })), inline assembly, wide-character/extended literal prefixes, or other known compiler extensions.

Notes on potentially ambiguous items (do not require investigation based on the provided source):
- The invocation of OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET is a macro call; macros can hide non-portable code, but the macro definition is not present here. The rule requires reporting explicit uses of language extensions as stated in compiler documentation; a macro call alone is not an explicit language extension in this source fragment.
- Calls to OS_SockAddrToString_Impl, OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl, and OS_strnlen are ordinary function calls; their implementations might use extensions, but those implementations are outside the submitted code and thus not reportable here.

Therefore, based on the source shown, there are no suspicious code fragments that use compiler language extensions and require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
